pros: The pace of work for scientists is nice, no need to take work home at all, just leave at 5pm. Honestly love working with so many of my coworkers. Real sense of pride that you are providing a worthwhile service to the UK.
cons: Unfortunately it is full of people that should never have been promoted to the positions they are in. Even worse is that it continues to happen in front of your eyes as people are promoted because they have been there the longest despite the fact that they should never have the responsibility of managing people. Also, people seemingly cannot be fired regardless of how little work they actually accomplish in a day.

review_title: Largest public sector healthcare organisation in the UK
pros: One of Scotland's largest employers. Great opportunities to work on range of services and developments.
cons: Large organisation to find way around,

pros: Great place to work, enjoy it.
cons: none, I have no complaints.

pros: Lovely people to work with
cons: often understaffed making it unnecessarily stressful

review_title: Awful! ..put it all back in the box!
pros: At best, most people are people focused and care about the NHS, at worst, the internal politics is like wading through treacle and when nurses and GP's should be putting bandages on people, they are all in IT meetings and laying down the law.  If only they themselves conformed to the concept of the patient driven service.
cons: Where do you start, a lot of people want to work in the NHS as they are dependent on others and for some reason go off sick and awful lot.  The concept of the patient driven service is a myth and the government lets down people very badly with its post code lottery.

review_title: Run well as a whole, however staff engagement from management is minimal
pros:
Fair in terms of decisions and grievances
Well funded in most areas
Great free exercise classes
Large trust so usually promotional opportunities available if you're prepared to work across Greater Glasgow
cons:
Little engagement from top management
Payroll staff sometimes difficult to work with
Sometimes a little hard to make forward changes due to costcutting.
I also had to start on a lower post than what I am qualified for as everyone starts at entry level regardless of education.

pros: Benefits are good, and there is job security when the job market is so unsteady if your willing there is a chance for promotion.  You can also get a lot of discounts in shops with your staff discount.  Again I you want you can learn more skills the access to learning courses are quite good.  Pensions are one of the better pension plans.
cons: Cons are very poor management unwilling to understand their staff brush problems under the carpet don't believe that bullying is an issue, when ever there's problems management are unwilling to admit that they could be the fault and not their staff. A lot of clinical management have absolutely no previous experience of managing as they are promoted from the clinical laboratory's.  A lot of management have no people skills and have no reservations about blaming other staff to make themselves look faultless.

pros: NHS Greater Glasgow & Clyde is Trust  like any other NHS Trusts in the UK. NHS is a public organisation and is considered to be a good employer.
cons: Opportunities for part-time work are limited as there are ever increasing staff shortages. Staff are getting overworked and are under ever increasing pressure to cope.

pros: Average employer, not very progressive, but also not too demanding. This means that there are people who just turn up every day and get paid. Unfortunately, the people who do a good job also just get paid.
cons: No real incentive to do an excellent job. Sometimes a real institutional negative culture. It does grind you down after a while. Not too many dynamic people around.

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: Try not to get tied down too much with the politics and 'red-tape' and it is a very rewarding career.  The health service is very persistent in wanting to develop my knowledge and skills into areas I have a personal interest in.
cons: My department is very heavily micro-managed.  There is no autonomy and this is very highly demotivating.

pros: Good environment to work in, colleagues are wonderful people, very challenging work at times. Steep learning curve, especially in the initial phases.
cons: Complete lack of respect from management and senior staff, lots of unpaid and even worse, unacknowledged overtime. Often a lack of senior support at difficult times, disorganisation at every level.

review_title: A useful place for building IT experience, but severely lacking in career opportunities
pros: Absolute job security, easy interview.
cons: Staff are promoted for political reasons, killing morale for everyone.  Personal development is only ever talked about - plans are put in place, and never executed.  Difficult to escape.

pros: Steady hours, good pension (I'm told), secure job
cons: Low pay, lack of progression opportunities, common for staff to feel like "just a number"

pros: The team was very supportive and were very happy to show me the ropes. They were very willing to help and really supported me when I fell ill
cons: Because I don't drive, getting there was a challenge. The bus route was very long and taxis to work were pretty expensive.
